channel.title: News on GIPS Project Site
channel.description: Recent content in News on GIPS Project Site

item.title: Publications
item.description:
GIPS has been applied in some application scenarios and domains. In the following, we provide a collection of relevant publications. If you are using or have used GIPS in a project, publication, lecture, or similar, please contact us.

List of Publications

2025

  • “GIPS: A Graph- and MILP-based Optimization Framework”.
    Sebastian Ehmes.
  • “Model-Driven Rapid Prototyping for Control Algorithms with the GIPS Framework (System Description)”.
    Maximilian Kratz, Sebastian Ehmes, Philipp Maximilian Menzel, Andy Schürr.

2024

  • “Generating Training Data Sets for Machine Learning Approaches with GIPS”.
    Maximilian Kratz, Sebastian Ehmes, Marco Volle, Andy Schürr.

2022

  • “Graph-Based Specification and Automated Construction of ILP Problems”.
    Sebastian Ehmes, Maximilian Kratz, Andy Schürr.

item.title: Projects
item.description:
GIPS has been applied in some application scenarios and domains. In the following, we provide a collection of some of our project implementations. If you are using or have used GIPS in a project, publication, lecture, or similar, please contact us.

Selected List of Projects

  • International Healthcare Timetabling Competition (IHTC) 2024
    • Our solution to the IHTC 2024
  • Class Responsibility Assignment (CRA)
  • Person to Task Assignment
  • lectureStudio Peer-to-Peer network example
    • Implementation of the paper “Model-Driven Rapid Prototyping for Control Algorithms with the GIPS Framework (System Description)”
    • Ready to use virtual machine to run the example
  • Model-driven Virtual Network Embedding
    • Implementation of the paper “Graph-Based Specification and Automated Construction of ILP Problems”

item.title: IHTC 2024 solution submitted
item.description:
We submitted a GIPS-based solution to the International Healthcare Timetabling Competition (IHTC) 2024.

Our solution can be found in the gips-examples repository.

item.title: Development
item.description:
GIPS is developed at the Real-Time Systems Lab, TU Darmstadt (TUDa). You can find the list of contributors on the GIPS developer page.

The source code of GIPS is available at our GitHub repository and it is based on eMoflon::IBeX.

GIPS-specific development workspace set-up steps are available in the README.md file of the GIPS repository. We recommend the usage of our pre-built Eclipse application to start your development workspace.

item.title: Contact
item.description:
You can send us an . Feel free to open issues on GitHub if you find any issues in GIPS.

Technische Universität Darmstadt
Department of Electrical Engineering and Information Technology
Real-Time Systems Lab
Merckstr. 25
64283 Darmstadt, Germany

item.title: Development Team
item.description:
GIPS is developed at the Real-Time Systems Lab, TU Darmstadt (TUDa). Feel free to contact us.

Current Developers

  • Sebastian Ehmes
  • Maximilian Kratz
  • Markus Blank

item.title: Download
item.description:
• Pre-built Eclipse Application (GIPS)
    • Pre-built Virtual Machine (GIPS VM)
    • Eclipse Update Site (GIPS)

There are three ways to download GIPS:

  1. The pre-built Eclipse application
  2. The pre-built virtual machine
  3. The Eclipse update site.

We recommend the usage of our pre-built Eclipse application.

Pre-built Eclipse Application (GIPS)

You can download the latest version of our pre-built Eclipse application from the release section of our GitHub repository.

There are several versions available for Windows, Linux, and macOS:

Pre-built Virtual Machine (GIPS VM)

You can download the latest version of our pre-built virtual machine image from the release section of our GitHub repository.

item.title: Getting started with GIPS
item.description:
To get started with GIPS, you can use our pre-built GIPS Eclipse application.

If you encounter any issues with the tutorial, feel free to open an issue on GitHub.
